work.title: Work
work.pitch: Let's speak a bit about what I do for a living.

experiences.name: Cordant Group
experiences.description: Cordant Group is one of the top recruitment companies in UK. The main domains covered by the company are managed services (for clients as Tesco, Amazon), security, facility management, IT staff recruitment and other. The company employs about 3 000 people in its core, and 50 000 overall.

projects.name: Cordant Connect
projects.quickDescription: Collection of micro services developped with cutting edge technologies, to ease the journey of candidates in the recruitment process.
achievements: Developped and deployed various fast growing apps with huge ROI for the buiness
Improved the coding and deployment process
Took the lead of a team of developpers
longDescriptions: Cordant Connect is a set of applications developped since late 2016 as microservices, to numerize and automate the work of Cordant Group employees, and to ease the journey of the candidates. It starts from the first contact the candidates have with the company (a call, an appointment in a branch), and goes all along the colleague's life in the company. The first applications have been a success and quickly acepted by both branch staff and candidates.

From a technical point of view, the project started as a PoC (front end developped in HTML + jQuery / Google Spreadsheet database), and has now a fully grown technical stack, taking advantage of the latest technologies as for instance Angular 4, AWS Lambda, Serverless, PostgresSQL Database, AWS DynamoDB (NoSQL database)...

projects.name: Spirit and Legacy
projects.quickDescription: Support and maintenance of the legacy systems, automation of some processes, and development of a new system for workers management.
achievements: Understanding the recruitment business through the user support and the applications
Catched up quickly on a project using proprietary language and complex algorithms and structure
Automated account creation for an application
longDescriptions: My first assignment at Cordant Group was to work on the legacy systems that are still woring nowadays, as well as working on a new project that was being developped. The legacy systems cover a large spectrum of Microsoft applications, as for example C# applications, ASP websites, SSIS, SSRS, SQL Server databases, as well as off the shelf products, as for instance RoleCall.

My second assignment was a project called Spirit, developped on ISIS Papyrus's proprietary platform, to create in the first place an application to onboard candidates, and in the second place a candidate management system.

experiences.name: CGI
experiences.description: CGI is an information technology and business process outsourcing company, strong of about 70 000 IT professionals. I worked in this company for about 4 years and a half, first as an intern, and then as an analyst developper. I worked for Dalkia (one of the main accounts for CGI Grenoble), a client managing heating and air conditioning systems in France and Italy.

projects.name: Sigma Liss
achievements: Improved the data interface of the application from 70% to 99.5%
Develpped several monitoring and automation tools for support
Deployed the application to about 30 users
longDescriptions: This project started some years before I joined the company, and wasn't quite used until the team changed. It became one of the main projects for Dalkia, as the cost reduction policy pointed out that the time spend on the field wasn't optimized. The idea for our team was to implement a part of the ARM solution developped by CGI U.S. and adapt it to Dalkia's context. The main challenge being the communication with Dalkia's other applications, the interface was a really critical subject, and was monitored hourly, with tools we developped inhouse. From the start of our intervention on the project to the end of my work on it, the interface fiability moved from 70% to 99%

From a technology point of view, the software was based on C++ code we couldn't act on, comunicating with an Oracle 10 database. The monitoring application was first based on Excel VBA macros, and has been moved slowly to a HTML / jQuery / Bootstrap front end, plugged to an Oracle Database.

projects.name: Energy
projects.quickDescription: Heating and air conditioning systems management.
achievements: Deployed new UI components and refreshed the design of the app
Earned business trust on complex subjects
Got to speed on an old and complicated application
longDescriptions: This project was a monster web application, managing the consumptions and budgeting of the heating and air conditioning systems Dalkia was working on. It had at the time about 250 users, with 50 working live. It was one of Dalkia's main applications, as holder of the information used for the invoicing process. It was though comunicating with about 20 other applications, and had about 25 Oracle batches running at night, and a 24 hours budget closure batch day at the end of the year.

Concerning technologies, it was a complicated super layered ASP.Net application, that we moved from .Net 2.0 to .Net 4.0, comunicating with an Oracle 10 Database. It used a Microsoft Silverlight component that I developped during my internship, to edit the technical schema of the systems.

list.name: 3D images - Webcam headtracker
list.pitch: What if a plane surface gave you the impression of 3D, with no glasses or VR headset? That is the idea of this project. Using ThreeJS and headtrackr, I managed to reproduce a '3D effect' on pictures I have taken and pre-processed. It has just been adapted to work with Angular.
explaination: The idea is simple but first of all, you have to have pictures. I took mine in Chiswick house and gardens park, London, UK, or during the Coupe Icare, Grenoble, France.
I then identified the pictures that were to be used, and edited them, so that they contained only graphical information relevant for the layer I wanted them to represent.
Then, ThreeJS and headtrackr provided respectively the 3D environment and the head location necessary to do the calculation to render the pictures.
The only remaining challenge was to play with depth and the virtual head to have this effect.
beforeTesting: This experience has been designed for desktops with webcam only, so please do not expect it to work properly on tablet or smartphone.
There is a defined set of scenes, feel free to press the left and right arrows of your keyboard to discover.
The next page will ask for your authorization to use the camera, it is for head tracking purpose only, no worries.
Please try to use as much light as you can on your face, this ease the process of face detection.
The video stream might not stop after you come back from the next screen, I am working on it, please reload the page if any issue.
It might be a little laggy, yet again, I was proud and happy with the result, I hope you will like it.

list.name: Ulam Spiral
list.pitch: Have you ever felt bored during some meetings? Well, Stanislaw Ulam did, got a piece of paper, and drew a spiral of the positive integers (Yeah, no Facebook in 1963). After drawing a few hundred points, he noticed managed to obtain a pretty graphical depiction of prime numbers, that offered a map of the density of prime numbers.
explaination: During some research work, I had a closer look into prime numbers, and a closer one to their representation: The Ulam Spiral.

The idea of this spiral is to represent all positive integers, in a spiral, and highlight the prime integers only. This work has done no major breakthrough on the comprehension of the prime numbers, but definitely gives an intriguing representation of the density of those numbers.
beforeTesting: This experience has been designed for desktops, so please do not expect it to work properly on tablet or smartphone.
You can zoom in/out with the mouse's wheel, and rotate draging your mouse on the screen.
